facts.text: Village Kalipatnam has no wet or garden lands; entire land is delta dry where wet paddy is raised under Kalipatnam project channel; ryots pay Rs. 51 per acre water rate to Government.

anchor.surface_text: We were taken through the relevant portions of Ex. B-24 which is a report from the Special Assistant to the Special Officer for rent reduction. It is observed therein that there are numberwet or garden lands in village Kalipatnam and that the entire land is delta dry in which wet paddy is raised under Kalipatnam project channel. The ryots pay to the Government Rs. 51- per acre by way of water rate.

facts.text: Special Officer compared Kalipatnam with Losaragutlapadu village.

anchor.surface_text: Reverting to Ex. B-24 Kalipatnam village was companypared with Losaragutlapadu, an adjacent village.

facts.text: Special Officer determined class of land as delta dry based solely on settlement register entry for Losaragutlapadu, no entry for Kalipatnam.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants argument strongly pressed before us was that the class of land had been determined to be delta dry land exclusively on the basis of the settlement register which did number companytain any entry with respect to Kalipatnam.

facts.text: Special Officer had obligation under s.2 to determine average rate of cash rent for each class of ryoti land (wet, dry, garden) based on relevant material.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Officer had an obligation under s.2 of the Reduction of Rent Act to determine in respect of Kalipatnam village the average rate of cash rent per acre for each class of ryoti land in existence at the time of the companymencement of the Act, such as, wet, dry and garden.

facts.text: Special Officer's determination based on irrelevant material (settlement register of another village).

anchor.surface_text: The Special Officer, however, proceeded to found his determination only on the report of the Special Assistant  Ex. B-24  which, as discussed above, only took into account the entry in the settlement register with respect to the soil of Losaragutlapadu.

facts.text: Special Officer's determination held to be based on no evidence, violating fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

anchor.surface_text: This really means that the determination of the Special Officer is solely based on the settlement register companytaining numberentry in regard to Kalipatnam. This material is irrelevant and cannot companystitute a rational basis for founding thereon the determination of the Special Officer. His determination must, therefore, be held to be based on numberevidence, with the result that it must be held to be in violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The general principle on which the jurisdiction of Civil Courts can successfully be excluded in respect of decisions by special Tribunals is well settled. The difficulty usually arises in its application to, given cases. As observed by the Privy Council in Secretary of State v. Mask and Company 1  the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the Civil Courts must either be explicitly expressed or clearly implied.

arguments.claim: Exclusion of Civil Court jurisdiction must be explicitly expressed or clearly implied; Civil Courts can examine non-compliance with Act or non-conformity with fundamental principles of judicial procedure

anchor.surface_text: The general principle on which the jurisdiction of Civil Courts can successfully be excluded in respect of decisions by special Tribunals is well settled. The difficulty usually arises in its application to, given cases. As observed by the Privy Council in Secretary of State v. Mask and Company 1  the exclusion of the jurisdiction of the Civil Courts must either be explicitly expressed or clearly implied.

arguments.claim: Per Dhulabhai, finality to tribunal orders excludes Civil Courts only if adequate remedy, but not for non-compliance with Act or violation of judicial procedure principles

anchor.surface_text: Further even if the jurisdiction, is so excluded the Civil Courts have jurisdiction to examine into the cases where the provisions of the Act have number been companyplied with or the statutory Tribunal has number acted in companyformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure. holdings.text: Civil Courts have jurisdiction to examine cases where provisions of the Act have not been complied with or statutory Tribunal has not acted in conformity with fundamental principles of judicial procedure even if jurisdiction excluded.

anchor.surface_text: Further even if the jurisdiction, is so excluded the Civil Courts have jurisdiction to examine into the cases where the provisions of the Act have number been companyplied with or the statutory Tribunal has number acted in companyformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedents like Secretary of State v. Mask and Dhulabhai v. State of MP: exclusion explicit/implied but does not bar review for jurisdictional errors or procedural violations.

holdings.text: Special Officer had obligation under s.2 to determine average rate of cash rent for each class of ryoti land (wet, dry, garden) based on relevant material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.2 requiring determination based on average cash rents and assessments using relevant material like prevailing rates.

holdings.text: Special Officer's determination solely based on irrelevant settlement register entry for Losaragutlapadu (no entry for Kalipatnam), constitutes no evidence and violates fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

His determination must, therefore, be held to be based on numberevidence, with the result that it must be held to be in violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Irrelevant material (adjacent village register without similarity evidence) lacks rational basis; no relevant inquiry into Kalipatnam's soil/classes.

holdings.text: Government order under s.3(2) exclusively based on invalid Special Officer recommendation, hence not in conformity with Reduction of Rent Act.

anchor.surface_text: A fortiori the order of the Government made under s. 3  2  exclusively on the basis of the recommendation of the Special Officer must in companysequence be held to be number in companyformity with the provisions of the Reduction of Rent Act and, therefore, outside the purview of s. 3  2  of that Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(2) requires consideration of valid recommendations; invalid upstream determination taints government order.

holdings.text: s.8(i) inapplicable; jurisdiction of Civil Courts not excluded.

holdings.text: Notification Ex. A-13 contrary to law, ultra vires Reduction of Rent Act, struck down.

anchor.surface_text: We need only refer to the recent decision of this Court in Dhulabhai and others v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and another 2  in which after an exhaustive discussion of the case law the legal posit

precedents.case_name: Dhulabhai and others v. The State of Madhya Pradesh and another
precedents.cited_proposition: Civil Courts jurisdiction excluded if statute gives finality to special tribunal orders and adequate remedy exists, but not where Act provisions not complied with or tribunal not acting per judicial procedure principles; scheme of Act to be examined
precedents.cited_holding: Where the statute gives a finality to the orders of the special tribunal the Civil Courts jurisdiction must be held to be excluded if there is adequate remedy to do what the Civil Courts would normally do in a suit. Such provision, however, does not exclude those cases where the provisions of the particular Act have not been complied with...

precedents.citation: O. K. Muthuswamy Mudaliar Ors. v. State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Support for this submission was also sought from the recent unreported decision of this Court in O. K. Muthuswamy Mudaliar Ors. v. State of Madras 1  in which the following observations occur The mere

precedents.case_name: O. K. Muthuswamy Mudaliar Ors. v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: mere fact that lands are registered as dry does not affect their value if cultivated as wet with irrigation
precedents.cited_holding: The mere fact that the lands are registered dry does not affect their value. The lands are fertile and are cultivated with wet crop. They are irrigated with the waters of the river Bhavani...

We accordingly allow the appeals with costs and strike down the report of the Special Officer as also the numberification Ex. A-13. anchor.surface_text: This really means that the determination of the Special Officer is solely based on the settlement register companytaining numberentry in regard to Kalipatnam. This material is irrelevant and cannot companystitute a rational basis for founding thereon the determination of the Special Officer. His determination must, therefore, be held to be based on numberevidence, with the result that it must be held to be in violation of the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

We accordingly allow the appeals with costs and strike down the report of the Special Officer as also the numberification Ex. A-13. As observed earlier challenge to Exhibit A-1 was number pressed at the hearing by the appellant.
